Background Abstract EEG Respiration Temperature Team
Biometrics Dashboard

BACKGROUND

The MINTS Biometrics Dashboard is a desktop application that presents real-time biometric data visualizations. This dashboard augments the researcher’s ability to develop intuition and insights on physiological responses to dynamic environments. The application is integrated with the Cognionics Mobile-128 and AIM2 systems using the open-source LabStreamingLayer library.

Access Source Code

ABSTRACT

PURPOSE

This project aims to develop an application that visualizes several biometric makers in real-time. This project serves as a research tool in quantifying the impact of environmental factors on human physical and cognitive function. For example, the effect of air quality (particulate matter) on resting heart rate.

IMPLEMENTATION

The application consists of three modules: the EEG, Respiration, and Temperature module. Details on each module is given in the proceeding sections.

RESOURCES USED

The programming language of choice was Python, with use of the following packages: PyQt, PyQtGraph, PyLSL, numpy, and scipy. The dashboard reads in data via a LabStreamingLayer inlet for real-time analysis.

EEG MODULE

An electroencephalogram (EEG) is the recording of electrical activity on the surface of the brain. The EEG system used in this project consisted of 64 electrodes. The EEG module is divided into three sections based on brain wave frequency bands: Delta Band (0-4HZ), Theta Band(4-7HZ) and Alpha Band(8-12HZ). Each electrode presents a color that is associated with the power of that electrode in that frequency band. The z-score of the power is normalized (scaled between -1 and 1) and plotted. Separation of data in this way allows the user to observe the intensity of each range of frequency in that part of the brain and derive conclusions.

RESPIRATION MODULE

Respiration module is divided into 5 visualizations - SPO2, Heart Rate, PPG, ECG and Respiration Graph. The modules display the concentration of the oxygen in the blood, heart rate, blood volume changes, electrical activity of the heart, and the breaths/minute respectively. Both HR and SpO2 widgets also display a label depicting the body’s current condition based on the their values.

TEMPERATURE MODULE

The temperature module was split into three different submodules as mentioned in the implementation section: temperature, GSR and an accelerometer. additionally, the team used PyQTgraph and used many of its functions specifically to make some visualization widgets like the accelerometer output the data in a 3-dimensional plane. We concluded that this was the most efficient and clear way to present the values and the results of such decision were nothing but satisfactory.

ABOUT MINTS

MINTS is a research group based out of the William B. Hanson Center for Space Sciences at The University of Texas at Dallas, and is the sponsor for this project. The main vision for MINTS is facilitating proactive preparedness through preemptive sensing. Providing commanders, environment officers, and individuals actionable insights on multiple spatial and temporal scales for real time data driven decisions. Our sensing scales range from global satellite surveys to local weather stations and mobile units. While these former sensing platforms are geared toward the environment, in this project we focus on a new domain, the human body.
